title: Preliminary hearing of mother of girl who died in shooting continued to July 20
content:
QUINCY -- Karen L. Torres of Quincy, the mother of a 7-year-old girl who died in a shooting May 20 near Beverly, had her preliminary hearing continued Wednesday afternoon in Adams County Circuit Court.
Judge Robert Adrian advanced the hearing date to 1:30 p.m. July 20 at the request of Torres' attorney, Ryan Schnack, who wanted more time to examine evidence.
Investigators said the shooting of the girl, Melina Torres, occurred during a family gathering at Julie Roberts-Cole's home near Beverly. Roberts-Cole is Melina Torres' grandmother.
The cases of the three others arrested in connection with the shooting are in various stages.
º Roberts-Cole, 49, of Barry, had a preliminary hearing rescheduled to July 26 after her lawyer, Michael Ghidina, requested a continuance in Adams County Circuit Court. Roberts-Cole is charged with two counts of obstruction of justice. Police say Roberts-Cole gave false information to officers while they were investigating the death of her granddaughter.
º Daniel W. Roberts, 32, of Quincy, \uncle of Melina Torres, has pleaded not guilty to three felony charges, including endangering the life of a child. His trial is set for August.
Roberts faces the most serious charges, which also include possession of weapon by a felon and obstruction of justice, both felonies. He faces up to 10 years in prison if convicted. Police say Roberts placed a loaded .22-caliber rifle into the possession of a 3-year-old, which led to the death of Melina Torres. As a convicted felon, Roberts is not allowed to own a gun.
º Shannon Combes, 30, of Rockport, a family friend, will have a preliminary hearing July 26 on a charge of being a felon in possession of a weapon. According to information filed, Combes knowingly possessed a camouflage .22-caliber rifle with a scope despite having a felony conviction.
